citations.narrative:
There is damage to a bottom corner of 1 wired primary enclosure, resulting in several inches of mangled wire protruding
into the enclosure and creating larger openings in the remaining wire. Damaged wire may injure the dog and compromise
the structural integrity of the enclosure. Primary enclosures must be structurally sound and kept in good repair to minimize
risks to the dog contained therein.
Correct by 8/6/24.

The dogs are kept indoors during feeding times and overnight in enclosures that do not meet minimum space
requirements. Ten dogs are kept in enclosures offering 7.11 square feet of floor space. These dogs ranged between 38
inches and 46 inches long, necessitating minimum space of 12.25 square feet and 18.78 square feet, respectively.
Insufficient space may prevent dogs from being able to rest or move comfortably as well as restricting expression of
normal behaviors. Primary enclosures must provide for the minimum required floor space for each dog as described in
this section.
Correct by 8/27/24.

The facility does not offer continuous access to water for all dogs. Water is not offered to one 24-week-old dog overnight
for housebreaking purposes. In addition, while all dogs are offered fresh buckets of water during kenneled feeding times,
5 occupied kennels contained empty buckets that had not yet been replenished since the dogs finished drinking. No dogs
exhibited evidence of dehydration at the time of inspection. The facility must ensure all dogs on the premises have
continuous access to potable water unless restricted by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 8/2/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
